column5: Guess I'll need to "retrain" the Boys out here... And start calling them "WINGS".... Definetly, more appropriate....
Hey jimirjr, doesn't matter what you call them, I'm just wish'n I had more of them "bones" eh !!
never had heard of this before, but you guys got me hooked. I'll be making wings next year and have decided it's worth it to do the cheeks on all our keepers.

Quote: Originally Posted by tv4fishThis is just the way I do it. Take the point of your fillet knife and find the outer "edge" of any part of the cheek (where the soft cheek stops and bones start) - carefully insert the knife down through the skin and at an angle toward the middle of the cheek - then carefully cut around the entire cheek so your knife tip follows the outside of the soft cheek flesh. It will end up being a piece of flesh that tapers from the outside down to the center of the cheek, like a cone. Then flip the cheek so the skin is down, use a fingernail to hold the skin, and slide your knife at an angle to separate the skin from the flesh. There is no doubt that is much easier to do this on a larger walleye, as there is more flesh to deal with. Thanks Bobby, that's the 3rd or 4th time I've heard someone suggest sharpening a spoon and gouging the cheeks out so that sounds like something worth trying. Otherwise I'll have to start keeping those larger 25"-32" walleyes to practice on instead of our normal 16"-17" that we normally keep for meals. You know what kind of a Brou-ha-ha that would have started, and you know how I hate confrontation, so I'll use your suggestion.

I only had them once, and they were on decent sized fish (16 - 18 inches), and I thought they were OK . . . I didn't think there was much meat on them and I didn't think they were worth the hassle. I do LOVE cheeks though, and like the thought of utilizing more of the fish with the wings, but the one time I did try them I really wasn't very impressed. I may try it again after reading this, but I usually do like to eat those 15 and 16 inch fish and just don't see much meat there.
Anyone ever done this with other fish? I assume something like a northern would be good too?
Just looking at the pics make me hungry. Definitely a new part of the cleaning routine from now on. I bet a bag of those is a nice snack. Thanks for the tip guys! Blair
Walleye wings...who would have thunk. TVM
Let me know when they are almost ready,I can be at Indian Lk in less than 5 min.

A couple years ago while up at Eddie North's Beteau Lake, Eddie showed us how to do the walleye wings. We do it now on all our kept walleyes. Much easier than getting the cheeks out. I haven't found an easy way for them yet.

This is just the way I do it. Take the point of your fillet knife and find the outer "edge" of any part of the cheek (where the soft cheek stops and bones start) - carefully insert the knife down through the skin and at an angle toward the middle of the cheek - then carefully cut around the entire cheek so your knife tip follows the outside of the soft cheek flesh. It will end up being a piece of flesh that tapers from the outside down to the center of the cheek, like a cone. Then flip the cheek so the skin is down, use a fingernail to hold the skin, and slide your knife at an angle to separate the skin from the flesh. There is no doubt that is much easier to do this on a larger walleye, as there is more flesh to deal with.

Hey draco, my wife suggested sharpening a tea spoon, so I thought a smaller(sugar spoon) would work better, so I put an edge on the tip with a grinder and just stick it into the beginning of the cheek and then gouge them out, they almost pop right out. Makes my mouth water just talking about them!! Come on May !!!
I must admit, I have never heard of "walleye wings" before. Now I'm curious and may try them next time I get a walleye, thanks.
Cheeks

I learned how to do "wings" and cheeks a long time ago but I just don't bother with them now. Next summer I am going to have to start again. The wings are best meat on a walleye. I just fry in butter and garlic, no breading at all.

Our group calls the wings "Poor Mans Shrimp". We take the wings and, using a knife, usually heavier than a fillet knife, split the wings into two equal pieces. When you deep fry them you can use the fin as a handle, like the tail of a shrimp. The meat will slide right off into your mouth leaving the fin and bone in your hand. Very tasty and fun to eat.

I just finished my last bag of walleye "wings", it's a sad day, BUT, opener is down the road and it will be time to replenish my stocks of walleye "wings and cheeks. Any of you guys eat walleye "wings" and cheeks??
10-4!! I save all the wings and cheeks and those are for football halftime in the winter, or an appie for a planning session for Canada.

By wings I'm assuming you are talkin about the two fins under the belly of the walleye? I've had some american clients do this they swore it was awesome. Keeping cheeks is a must! If you don't have enough at the end of the day just save them up for the week and have a big feast! I cook them like I would cook a scallop or I wrap them in bacon. Then again anything wrapped in bacon is good!
Out West we call the 'wings' ... the "Wishbones" For some reason unbeknownst to me....
In my group we call those shrimp and yes, they are fantastic!
We do the cheeks, but have never done the "wings". Can someone please fill me in? What are you saving and cooking? Also, how do you prepare the "wings"? Maybe something new for 2015... Blair

BCMSS396 go on youtube and punch in walleye wings there's a guy doing a video all about "wings", you can saute them, batter em, bake em , you can't go wrong any way you do them, the fins fry up nice and crunchy! YUMO!!
If you don't want to do the youtube thing:http://myfishingpartner.com/walleye-wings/
TV, Great photo. It says beware of the bones however. Can the wings be boned prior to frying or eat around them like trout?
I think it best to "eat around them". (Personally I STILL prefer the cheeks). Otherwise, eat these like shrimp with the tail still on.
